<summary>

• The transport properties of chaotic deterministic ratchets are complex and depend on the details of the initial ensemble and the presence of transients.
• The current for an ensemble is defined as the time-average of the average velocity over an ensemble of initial conditions.
• In chaotic trajectories, a single trajectory may display behavior very different from that of many trajectories, but in the regular regime, a single trajectory can give essentially the same result as obtained from many trajectories.
• The current is not independent of the location of the initial ensemble, especially for small ensemble sizes, and the width of the ensemble can also affect the details of the current.
• Not all bifurcations lead to current reversals, and not all current reversals are associated with bifurcations.
• The current changes significantly as a function of parameter, and bifurcations correspond to sudden current changes (spikes or jumps).
• The physical basis of this argument is the fact that ensembles of particles in chaotic systems can have net directed transport, but the details of this behavior depend relatively sensitively on the system parameters.
• The open question is to figure out if the reasons for when these rules are violated or are valid can be made more concrete.

</summary>

<summary>

* The text discusses the results of observations and simulations of six extrasolar planetary systems with highly eccentric planets.
* The observations were made using the Hobby-Eberly Telescope (HET) and other telescopes, and the data were analyzed to determine the architecture of these planetary systems.

<summary>
• The first proposal for using a single electron's spin polarization to encode binary information is attributed to Feynman, but concrete schemes for implementing spintronic logic gates did not exist until the mid 1990s.
• Spintronic logic gates may have advantages such as lower power dissipation, immunity to noise, and faster operation compared to charge-based devices.
• In 1994, a scheme was proposed for realizing a classical universal logic gate (NAND) using three spins placed in a weak magnetic field.
• Exchange interaction between neighboring spins prefers anti-ferromagnetic ordering (two neighboring spins are anti-parallel) over ferromagnetic ordering (two spins are parallel).
• The ground state of the array has the spin configuration shown in the figure, with upspin and downspin states defined.
• When two inputs are logic 1, the output will be logic 0 in the ground state. When two inputs are logic 0, the output must be logic 1 to conform to the anti-ferromagnetic ordering.
• However, the system may get stuck in a metastable state (Fig. 1(b)) due to the weak magnetic field, which may take a long time to decay to the ground state (Fig. 1(a)).
• Exchange interaction is bidirectional, which cannot ensure unidirectional flow of logic signals from the input to the output of the logic device.
• In 1996, a more elegant solution was proposed to propagate the input state through a linear array by lowering two adjacent barriers pairwise at the same time, requiring a three-phase clock.

<summary>

• Cataclysmic variables (CVs) are short-period binary systems with a white dwarf primary and a low-mass main sequence secondary. The secondary fills its Roche lobe and transfers mass to the white dwarf through the inner Lagrangian point.
• The main features of the orbital period distribution of CVs with hydrogen-rich donors are the lack of systems in the 2-3 hr period range (the period gap) and the sharp cut-off at around 77 minutes.
• Theoretical models have been unable to reproduce the precise position of the observed short-period cut-off and the shape of the CV orbital period distribution near this cut-off.
• Systems that evolve under the influence of gravitational radiation (GR) as the only sink of orbital angular momentum reach a minimum period at around 65 minutes. The probability of finding a system within a given period range is proportional to the time taken to evolve through this region.
• The orbital period evolution reflects the radius evolution of the mass donor, which in turn is governed by two competing effects: mass transfer and thermal relaxation. The minimum period occurs where the mass transfer time and the thermal (Kelvin-Helmholtz) time are about equal.
• The position of the minimum period is affected by the assumed mass transfer rate and the assumed rate of orbital angular momentum losses. The study investigates ways to increase the period minimum by increasing the mass transfer rate and ways to "hide" the spike by introducing a spread of CV populations.
• The study considers the effect of a form of consequential angular momentum loss (CAML) where the angular momentum is lost as a consequence of the mass transferred from the secondary. The calculations show that the minimum period increases with increasing CAML efficiency to a maximum of around 70 minutes, and mass transfer stability sets an upper limit on the CAML efficiency.

</summary>

<summary>

- Colliding plane waves (CPW) result in spacelike singularities, but these can be weakened by endowing the waves with a relative cross polarization or by coupling them with an electromagnetic (EM) field.
- Chandrasekhar and Xanthopoulos (CX) gave a solution with a Cauchy horizon (CH) instead of a spacelike singularity, initiating a literature on the stability of horizons formed in CPW.
- Yurtsever showed that the CH formed in spacetimes of CPW was unstable against plane-symmetric perturbations, and CX revealed an analogous result through linear perturbation analysis.
- Any perturbation applied to a CPW spacetime will turn the CH into an essential singularity.
- Cross polarization and the EM field both play roles in the nature of resulting singularities, so it's worthwhile to pursue these features together.
- The cpbs solution, a cross-polarized version of the Bell-Szekeres (BS) solution, was found long ago and has the nice feature that the weyl scalars are all regular in the interaction region.
- The singularities formed on the null boundaries cannot be removed by any means, but the weyl scalars are all regular in the interaction region for the cpbs solution.
- The hk stability conjecture proposes that for all maximally extended spacetimes with a CH, the backreaction due to a field will affect the horizon in one of three ways: the CH remains non-singular, an nsc singularity forms, or an sc singularity forms.
- The paper looks at spacetimes with a single plane wave with added colliding test fields and colliding plane waves having non-singular interaction regions with test field added, and uses the terminology of singularities from Ellis and Schmidt's classification.
</summary>

<summary>

- Quantum systems can exhibit correlations that cannot be explained by classical descriptions, with degrees of non-classicality ranging from non-separable (entangled) states to Bell-nonlocal states.
- Bell-nonlocal states violate Bell inequalities, demonstrating the violation of local causality, and are the only way for two spatially separated parties to verify the existence of entanglement if either of them or their detectors cannot be trusted.
- EPR-steerability is a weaker form of non-classical correlation that allows one party to steer the state of the other by measurements on their own system. It was only formalized eight years ago and is the only way to verify the existence of entanglement if one party's devices cannot be trusted.
- The steering ellipsoid formalism is a mathematical tool used to study the phenomenon of steering in quantum systems. It was used in this manuscript to investigate the epr-steerability of the class of two-qubit states whose reduced states are maximally mixed, called t-states.
- The authors developed a deterministic local hidden state (LHS) model for projective measurements on these t-states using the steering ellipsoid formalism and conjectured that it is optimal. They also obtained two sufficient conditions for t-states to be epr-steerable via suitable epr-steering inequalities.
- The authors found that the sufficient conditions touch the necessary condition in some regions of the space of t-states and are very close to it elsewhere. They also showed that the epr-steerability of a quantum state is related to the quantum steering ellipsoid, specifically for the case that the bloch vectors of the two parties vanish.
- The authors concluded that their results provide a better understanding of the relationship between epr-steerability and the quantum steering ellipsoid and have implications for the study of non-classical correlations in quantum systems.
</summary>

• Type 1 AGNs exhibit diverse broad and narrow emission lines, with broad lines thought to originate in or near an accretion disk.
• Two populations of Type 1 AGNs have emerged: population A with smaller broad-line widths and population B with larger broad-line widths.
• Population A sources, which include narrow line Seyfert 1 (NLSY1) sources, have best-fit hα profiles described by a single Lorentz function.
• Population B sources, which involve a mix of radio-quiet and radio-loud quasars, require two Gaussians for a reasonable profile description.
• Broad hα profiles in population B sources show two components: a classical broad component with zero or small shift and a very broad and redshifted component.

- The short-lived radioisotope @xmath4al was present during the formation of the first refractory solids in the solar nebula, and its injection into the solar system may have occurred through a supernova or AGB star shock wave.
- The solar system's SLRIs may have been injected into the presolar cloud or the solar nebula, leading to spatial heterogeneity that could reduce their usefulness as spatially homogeneous chronometers for precise studies of the earliest phases of planet formation.

<summary>

• Threshold nets are obtained by assigning weights to nodes and connecting nodes with combined weights exceeding a threshold.
• They can produce graphs with various degree distributions, including scale-free graphs.
• Threshold nets have been studied extensively in graph theory and recently gained attention in statistical and non-linear physics.
• They have a modular structure, with nodes of two types connecting differently.
• Threshold nets can be encoded using a two-letter sequence, with nodes of one type connecting to none and nodes of another type connecting to all.
• The modularity of threshold nets allows for fast computation of structural benchmarks like degree distribution, triangles, betweenness centrality, and eigenvalues.
• Threshold nets have limitations, such as a diameter of 1 or 2, regardless of the number of nodes.
• Sequence nets are a broader class of nets constructed from a sequence using deterministic rules of connectivity.
• Sequence nets retain the modularity and easily computable structural measures of threshold nets, but allow for more latitude in the types of nets that can be described.
• Sequence nets gain much latitude in the types of nets that can be described while retaining much of the analytical appeal of threshold nets.

</summary>

<summary>

* The solar corona is heated to 12 million kelvins while the photosphere is roughly 250 times cooler.
* Magnetic fields or waves are responsible for converting convective energy into thermal energy in the corona.
* The primary energy source for coronal heating lies in the convection zone below the photosphere.
* Debate continues on whether MHD waves or numerous magnetic reconnection events (nanoflares) heat the corona.
* Interaction of magnetic fields with convective flows generates MHD waves and twisting/braiding of coronal field lines.
* Wave-heating and current-heating are two types of magnetic heating mechanisms in the solar corona.
* Observations of high-frequency intensity oscillations in coronal structures have been made using the SECIS instrument.
* The SECIS instrument, installed at the Lomnicky Peak Observatory, will be used to search for high-frequency coronal oscillations.
</summary>

The text also explains that there are two types of magnetic heating mechanisms: wave-heating and current-heating. The text provides examples of observations made using the SECIS instrument and mentions that a new setup will be used to search for high-frequency coronal oscillations at the Lomnicky Peak Observatory.

- Nuclear multifragmentation is a topic of intense study due to potential signs of a liquid-gas phase transition in nuclear matter. Theoretical calculations started in the 1980s, while the first experimental evaluation of the nuclear caloric curve was reported in 1995 by the ALADIN group. A wide plateau was identified, suggesting the possible existence of a liquid-gas phase transition.
- Recent reevaluations of the ALADIN group's data have brought corrections to the kinetic energies of emitted neutrons and the energies of spectator parts, which grow with approximately 30 MeV in the bombarding energy interval 600 to 1000 MeV/nucleon. The universality of the quantity subject to the bombarding energy variation suggests that the equilibrated sources sequence should be the same for the mentioned reactions.
- The microcanonical multifragmentation model has been improved by refining the primary break-up part and including the secondary particle emission. The caloric curve reevaluated with the new version of the model preserves its general aspect, manifesting an important plateau-like region. The transition regions are clearly indicated by the sharp maxima of the constant volume heat capacity curves.
- The model proves its ability to simultaneously fit the "definitory" characteristics of the nuclear multifragmentation phenomenon, such as the multiplicity of intermediate mass fragments and charge asymmetry. The equilibrated source sequence is used to identify a nonequilibrium part of the experimentally evaluated excitation energy growing with the increase of the bombarding energy. The direct comparison of the calculated heli caloric curve shows an excellent agreement with the experimental heli curves recently evaluated by the ALADIN group.

• The classification problem is crucial in time series data mining, and 1-nearest neighbor (1-nn) with dynamic time warping (DTW) distance is an effective solution.
• DTW distance is more appropriate than Euclidean distance for time series data, and Sakoe-Chiba band (SC band) is a well-known global constraint for DTW.
• Recent research reveals that the optimal size of the SC band depends on the data properties, and the Ratanamahatana-Keogh band (R-K band) is a multi-dimensional array to generalize the global constraint model.
• R-K band allows adjusting the global constraint according to each class, but a learning algorithm is needed to discover the best multi R-K bands.
• The original R-K band learning algorithm suffers from overfitting due to the accuracy metric used as a heuristic function.
• Two new learning algorithms, band boundary extraction and iterative learning, are proposed to address the overfitting problem.
• The proposed algorithms use the silhouette index as a heuristic function to select the best multi R-K bands.
• The proposed algorithm uses 1-nn with DTW distance and the discovered multi R-K bands as a global constraint for time series classification.

• The text discusses the origin of celestial gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) and the search for associated gravitational waves (GWs).
• GRBs are powerful flashes of gamma rays lasting from less than one second to tens of seconds, with isotropic distribution in the sky.
• At least long GRBs are at cosmological distances, with measured redshifts up to 4.5.

- The text discusses the prediction of the Higgs boson mass in the Standard Model (SM) and how it is correlated with the top quark mass. The authors use global fits to precision measurements to infer information about the parameters of new models with physics beyond the SM.
- The authors demonstrate that the SM prediction for the Higgs boson mass is strongly correlated with the experimentally measured value of the top quark mass and increases quadratically as the top quark mass is increased. They also show that this correlation can be used to limit the allowed region for the Higgs boson mass in models with new physics.
- The authors discuss two examples of models with new physics that do not decouple from the SM at one loop, and demonstrate that the SM is not recovered when the scale of the new physics becomes much larger than the electroweak scale. They also discuss the possibility of a heavy Higgs boson that is consistent with precision electroweak data and the implications for oblique corrections.

- The study focuses on the effects of inert sites on the phase transitions of the Ziff, Gulari, and Barshad (ZGB) surface reaction model, which describes the oxidation of species over a catalytic surface. The model is a variant of the original ZGB model, where inert sites are randomly distributed over the lattice.
- Within the site approximation, the system exhibits a reactive steady state for all values of the concentration of inert sites, but no continuous transition for all values. The presence of inert sites allows for the formation of tolerated nearest-neighbor pairs, which explains the absence of a continuous phase transition. The pair approximation, on the other hand, yields both continuous and first-order transitions.

• Grb 090510 was observed by various satellites and telescopes, providing unprecedented data from the optical to high energy ranges.
• Theoretical analyses within the synchrotron/self-synchrotron compton (SSC) and traditional afterglow models were applied to understand the broadband emission of grb 090510.
• However, it has become clear that grbs can be subdivided into various classes and sub-classes, each requiring specific theoretical treatments and understanding.

• The findings from grb 090510 are expected to lead to a deeper understanding of the equally jetted GEV emission observed in various systems harboring a Kerr BH.

• A log-Riemann surface is a pair of a Riemann surface and a local holomorphic diffeomorphism such that the set of added points in the completion is discrete.
• Log-Riemann surfaces of finite type are certain branched coverings of the Riemann sphere given by transcendental functions of infinite degree.
• A log-Riemann surface consists of a Riemann surface, a local holomorphic diffeomorphism, and the set of added points in the completion.
• The map restricted to a small punctured neighborhood of a point gives a covering of a punctured disc or a half-plane.
• A log-Riemann surface is of finite type if it has finitely many ramification points and a finitely generated fundamental group.

• Exp-algebraic curves are a less rigid structure than log-Riemann surfaces, given by a compact Riemann surface and equivalence classes of germs of meromorphic functions with poles at punctures.
• The space of meromorphic sections of a line bundle and the space of meromorphic line-valued forms are naturally isomorphic, and the correspondence gives a one-to-one correspondence between exp-algebraic structures and degree zero line bundles with meromorphic connections.
• The theorem states that two exp-algebraic curves with the same underlying Riemann surface, the same set of punctures, isomorphic line bundles, and the induced isomorphism mapping divisors are equal.

• The parallel chip-firing game is a periodic automaton on graphs where vertices contain chips and fire them to neighbors if possible.
• At each move, a vertex fires if it has enough chips, and all vertices fire simultaneously.
• Kominers and Kominers showed that the period and transient length exist for all positions on connected graphs.
• Bitar and Goles showed that the period of a position on a tree graph is 1 or 2.
• The parallel chip-firing game is a special case of the chip-firing game and an example of an abelian sandpile model.
• The game has nontrivial computing capabilities, including simulating classical logic gates and two-register machines.
• The game can be used to model a deterministic fixed-energy sandpile, a subset of spatially extended dynamical systems.
• Self-organized critical models like the abelian sandpile display real-life properties such as noise, fractal patterns, and power law distribution.
• The game is an example of a cellular automaton, with implications from biology to social science.
• In this paper, we establish lemmas about parallel chip-firing games on simple connected graphs, find every possible period for the complete bipartite graph, and construct positions with period for all n on the complete bipartite graph.

- Myles Hollander began his college career at Carnegie Mellon as an engineering major, but switched to mathematics after being recruited by the math department. He was influenced by professors David Moscovitz and Morrie Degroot, who encouraged him to pursue statistics.
- Hollander went on to earn his PhD in statistics at Stanford, where he was part of a talented cohort of students including Brad Efron, Howard Taylor, and Joe Eaton. He was particularly influenced by Lincoln Moses, who became his role model and mentor.
- Hollander's research focused on nonparametric statistics, including the development of inference procedures for the hyperparameter of Ferguson's Dirichlet process, which laid the foundation for empirical Bayes treatment of nonparametric estimation.
- Throughout his career, Hollander has been dedicated to promoting nonparametric statistics and bringing it into other areas, inspiring many students to contribute to the field.

</summary>

• The paper discusses the hydrodynamic limit of interacting particle systems on the crystal lattice.
• The crystal lattice is a generalization of classical lattices and has periodic global structures but inhomogeneous local structures.
• The authors motivate the study of these problems due to their origins in statistical mechanics and hydrodynamics.
• They deal with the simplest extension of the euclidean lattice, the crystal lattice, which has geometric structures.
• The crystal lattice is formulated as an abelian covering graph, and its standard realization is used to characterize an equilibrium configuration of crystals.
• The authors construct a scaling limit of a crystal lattice by taking the quotient of the graph by a finite index subgroup and embedding it into a torus.
• They obtain exclusion processes embedded by the embedding map into the torus and deal with the symmetric simple exclusion process and its perturbation, the weakly asymmetric simple exclusion process.
• The diffusion coefficient matrices and nonlinear drift terms can be computed by data of a finite quotient graph and a harmonic map.
• The hydrodynamic limit for these processes on the crystal lattice is obtained as an extension of the one on the euclidean lattice.
• The paper reviews the outline of the proof for the hydrodynamic limit on the euclidean lattice and introduces the replacement theorem for crystal lattices.

</summary>

<summary>

- The text discusses recent progress in understanding strongly correlated electronic systems using dynamical mean field theory (DMFT) merged with local density approximation (LDA) for electronic structure calculations.
- The authors aim to develop self-consistent electronic structure algorithms that can explore all parameter space where neither doping nor degeneracy is fixed.
- DMFT simulations require fast scans of the entire parameter space to determine the interaction for a given doping, degeneracy, and bandwidth via the solution of the general multiorbital Anderson impurity model (AIM).
- Present approaches based on non-crossing approximation (NCA) or iterative perturbation theory (IPT) are unable to provide the solution to this problem due to a limited number of regimes where these methods can be applied.
- The quantum Monte Carlo (QMC) technique is very accurate but not suitable for multiplet interactions or a large number of orbitals due to its computational cost.
- Impurity solvers that improve upon the NCA approximation have been developed but cannot retrieve fermi liquid behavior at very low temperatures in the orbitally degenerate case.
- The authors propose an interpolative approach for the self-energy in the general multiorbital situation, following the ideology of LDA theory where approximations were designed by analytical fits to QMC simulations.
- The interpolative method can achieve a fast algorithm for the self-energy by utilizing a rational representation, and the coefficients in this interpolation can be found by forcing the self-energy to obey several limits and constraints.
- The authors test the slave boson mean field (SBMF) approach and the Hubbard I approximation to determine the functional dependence of these coefficients upon doping, degeneracy, and the strength of the interaction.
- The results show that the SBMF approach can predict the parameters of interpolation with good accuracy while the Hubbard I method fails in some regimes, but the functional form of the atomic green function within Hubbard I can be used to determine positions of atomic satellites and impose additional constraints on the procedure.
</summary>

• The text discusses a model that generates non-zero neutrino masses and mixing patterns using the @xmath1 symmetry.
• The model was first introduced by E. Ma and G. Rajasekaran and has since been extensively studied.
• It predicts tri-bi maximal mixing in the leptonic sector and admits hierarchical masses for the charged leptons and quasi-degenerate or hierarchical neutrino masses.
• The model also allows for the possibility of non-zero CP violation in the leptonic sector.
• The authors investigate the generation of non-zero neutrino masses through the see-saw mechanism by considering a small perturbation in the Dirac neutrino mass matrix.
• They study the detailed phenomenology of neutrino mass and mixing including CP violation at low energy, neutrinoless double beta decay, and leptogenesis.
• The approach to obtaining nonzero neutrino masses is minimal, as it breaks @xmath1 symmetry explicitly by a single parameter in a single element of the Dirac mass matrix.
• The generation of CP violation at low energy as well as high energy is also minimal, as it considers only one parameter complex.
• The model is based on a fabricated Lagrangian that gives rise to diagonal charged lepton and slepton mass matrices along with a competent texture of neutrino mass matrices.
• The model consists of several scalar fields to generate required vacuum alignment to obtain tri-bi maximal mixing.

</summary>

- The text discusses the interaction between many particles, focusing on the pair potential or forces between a single pair. Linear physical equations yield quantitatively reliable descriptions, but nonlinearities lead to many-body effects, which can result in changes to the total force acting on a particle, the appearance of stable or unstable configurations, or a change of sign of the force.
- The authors assess the influence of many-body effects on critical casimir forces (CCFs), which arise due to the confinement of order parameter fluctuations in a critical fluid. They add one sphere to a sphere-wall configuration to study many-body forces and use field-theoretic mean field theory (MFT) to compute the forces between individual pairs and three-body forces on the same footing.
- The authors find that the many-body contribution to the normal and lateral CCFs is attractive for all bcs considered when the surface-to-surface distances between the spheres and sphere-surface-to-substrate distances are equal. They also compare their results with those for quantum-electrodynamic casimir interactions and the Mclachlan model for the many-body contribution to the van der Waals potential.
</summary>

<summary>

• Organic molecular crystals, composed of organic molecules held together by weak van der Waals forces, are emerging as candidates for nanoscale devices in electronics and optoelectronics.
• These devices consist of both organic and inorganic components, where the organic part forms the active part and the inorganic part provides electrical contact.
• The electronic structure of the interface between the organic and inorganic components plays a crucial role in determining the device performance.
• Charge transfer between the organic and inorganic components and the energies at which transfer takes place need to be understood.
• Upon adsorption on a substrate, electron addition and removal energies of a molecule change due to the formation of image charges.
• Quasiparticle (qp) description is a common way to calculate addition and removal energies, but its adequacy depends on the level of theory used.
• Density functional theory (DFT) is a popular choice for calculating energy levels, but it fails to capture the non-local nature of image charge formation.
• An explicit many-body approach, such as the GW approximation, can capture image charge effects but is computationally demanding.
• Constrained density functional theory (CDFT) is a more resource-efficient alternative for calculating charge transfer energies between an organic molecule and an inorganic substrate.
• In this study, CDFT is used to investigate the adsorption of a benzene molecule on a 2D metal, specifically graphene, and the effect of defects and neighboring molecules on charge transfer energies.

</summary>

* MOPED is a patented algorithm for compressing data and speeding up likelihood evaluations in astronomical data analysis. It eliminates the need for matrix inversion by compressing data into independent, unit variance values.
* However, MOPED only maintains the Fisher matrix of the likelihood at a chosen point and can't accurately represent multimodal or degenerate distributions. The authors report on some of its limitations and provide solutions for certain scenarios.
* In the one-dimensional case of estimating the central frequency of a sine-gaussian burst signal, MOPED creates a second peak of equal height at an incorrect frequency due to a many-to-one mapping between the original and compressed parameters.
* Adding a second parameter, such as the burst width, can rectify the problem by creating two orthogonal weighting vectors and two compressed parameters, but only if the degeneracies coincide. MOPED can also create additional peaks in more complex scenarios, making parameter estimation challenging.

<summary>

- The star formation rate (SFR) of galaxies is crucial for understanding the hierarchical build-up of the universe. Large scale simulations suggest that unregulated star formation leads to an overabundance of high mass galaxies, necessitating processes to quench star formation.
- Supermassive black holes (SMBH) in the centers of massive galaxies are the likely solution to this problem. They grow through accretion of cold material, converting gravitational energy into radiation that manifests as a bright point source in the nucleus of galaxies.
- Indirect evidence of AGN feedback includes scaling relationships between the mass of the SMBH and different properties of the host galaxy, such as stellar velocity dispersion, bulge mass, and bulge luminosity. These relationships suggest a strong coevolution of the host galaxy and SMBH.
- Debate remains regarding the exact mechanism of AGN feedback and its role in the overall evolution of galaxies, particularly in light of new observations at low and high redshifts that deviate from established relationships. Much work has focused on the starburst-AGN connection, but accurate estimates of the SFR in AGN host galaxies are needed to determine the impact of AGN on star formation.
</summary>

- The atom in an atomic clock does not tick, requiring an active oscillator in addition to the atoms.
- Two problems arise in designing an atomic clock: the resonance of atoms varies with clock construction and operation, and the oscillator drifts in relation to its control knob.
- Problem (a) is addressed by introducing a wave function parametrized by radiation intensity and other factors, defining the second based on the resonance at absolute zero temperature.
- Problem (b) is dealt with by computer-mediated feedback that adjusts the oscillator based on detections of scattering of the oscillator's radiation by the clock's atoms.
- The wave function used in an atomic clock can never be unconditionally known, leading to implications for the second as a unit of measurement, digital communications, and spacetime with a metric tensor.
- Clocks that generate UTC time are steered toward aiming points that depend on both a chosen wave function and an hypothesized metric tensor field in a curved spacetime.
- Guesses enter the operations of clocks through the computational machinery that steers them, requiring logic open to an inflow of inputs beyond the reach of calculation.
- The logical synchronization necessary for a channel connecting clock readings at transmission of symbols to clock readings at their reception depends on the interaction between evidence and hypotheses about signal propagation.
- Questions arise concerning patterns of channels, how to approach aiming points within acceptable phase tolerances, and how to respond to deviations from aiming points beyond tolerances, leading to a discipline of logical synchronization.
</summary>

<summary>

• IEEE 802.15.4 is a standard for low power, low data rate wireless personal area networks (WPANs), with a main aim of providing reliable protocol for wireless monitoring of patient health.
• It supports two types of topologies: star and peer-to-peer, and two modes of operation: beacon enabled (slotted) and non-beacon enabled (unslotted).
• The non-beacon enabled mode with star topology and csma/ca protocol is the focus of this analysis.
• The standard defines physical layer and MAC sublayer, and supports three distinct frequency bands, with 2.4 GHz being the most important due to its compatibility with other wireless technologies.
• The MAC protocols play a crucial role in network performance, with contention-based (csma/ca) and schedule-based (tdma) being the two main categories.
• The analysis in this paper focuses on the performance of IEEE 802.15.4 with non-beacon enabled mode, star topology, and csma/ca protocol.
• Previous studies have analyzed the performance of IEEE 802.15.4 with beacon-enabled mode and slotted csma/ca for different network settings, but not with varying data rates.
• An analytical model for non-beacon enabled mode of IEEE 802.15.4 MAC protocol is provided, with nodes using unslotted csma/ca operation for channel access and packet transmission.
• The analysis in this paper investigates the unreliability in IEEE 802.15.4 standard and regulates the channel access mechanism using an extensive simulation analysis of csma/ca algorithm.

</summary>

- Molecular hydrogen (H2) is the most abundant molecule in the universe and forms in interstellar medium (ISM) through the sticking of H atoms onto dust grains, primarily carbonaceous or silicate particles.
- The sticking of H atoms onto dust grains can also cool interstellar gas and form H2. In the ISM, a significant portion of available surface area for chemistry is in the form of very small grains or PAHs.
- PAHs, which are usually present at lower extinction levels, represent an important route to form H2 through hydrogenation on their edges. Neutral PAHs, when highly hydrogenated, are efficient catalysts for H2 formation.
- PAH cations, which are present at lower extinction levels and reside at the surfaces of PDRs, also represent an important route to form H2. The addition of the first H atom is predicted to be barrierless, and subsequent additions occur without a barrier for para dimers and with a reduced barrier for ortho dimers.
- Our experiment studied the hydrogenation of coronene cations in the gas phase using mass spectrometry. Odd hydrogenation states predominantly populate the mass spectrum, and the further hydrogenation of PAH cations is associated with a barrier if the number of attached H atoms is odd and no barrier if it is even.
- The results suggest that PAH cations can also exist in highly hydrogenated states in the interstellar medium and act as catalysts for H2 formation. The experiment demonstrated the feasibility of studying the hydrogenation of PAHs in the gas phase using a radiofrequency ion trap and time-of-flight mass spectrometry.

- The cosmological constant problem (CCP) in particle physics involves the pieces of the puzzle being the vacuum energy density that can be the cosmological constant, various sources of vacuum energy, and the vacuum energy density receiving large radiative corrections.
- The first piece of the puzzle is that the vacuum energy density can be the cosmological constant, with sources including zero point energy of each particle, energy from the Higgs potential after the breakdown of electroweak symmetry, and energy accompanying chiral symmetry breaking due to quark condensations.
- The second piece is that the vacuum energy density can receive large radiative corrections including a cutoff scale, and the zero point energy density is calculated using an effective potential at the one-loop level.
- The experimental value of the cosmological constant is estimated to be around 1.1 x 10^-52 cm^-3, and the vacuum energy density of the universe is theoretically given by the sum of the zero point energy density and other contributions from new physics.
- The third piece is that the existence of a large vacuum energy density threatens the stability of our solar system, and it seems natural to suppose that the classical gravitational field does not feel a large portion of the vacuum energy.
- The fourth piece is that the classical gravitational fields do not couple to a large portion of the vacuum energy effectively, and external gravitons can couple to gravitational corrections of vacuum energy involving internal gravitons.
- The fifth piece is that the evolution of dark energy is described by the equation of state, and the logarithmically changing energy density is derived after the zero point energy density is regarded as the dark energy density and the temperature is identified with the radius of our universe.
- The sixth piece is that the potential changes after the incorporation of zero point energies of particles and the breakdown of symmetry, and the logarithmically changing energy density is described by the van der Waals type equation of state.

</summary>

• The underlying dynamics at each site possess two different timescales of oscillation.

• The frequency of the characteristic oscillation is a monotonic function of the external field in the ordered phase and becomes independent of the field when it crosses the critical value to the disordered phase.

* The study of dipole moments of elementary particles has provided significant insights into subatomic physics for over 83 years.
* From the pioneering work of Stern through the discovery of large anomalous magnetic moments of the proton and neutron, the groundwork was laid for the discovery of spin, radiative corrections, and the renormalizable theory of QED.
* A charged particle with spin has a magnetic moment, where the gyromagnetic ratio, anomaly, and latter expression are given.
* The Dirac equation states that for spin one-half point-like particles, the magnetic moment is given by the spin angular momentum and is unity for orbital angular momentum.
* For point particles, the anomaly arises from radiative corrections, and two examples of these are shown in Figs. a and b.
* The situation for baryons is different due to their internal quark structure, which gives them large anomalies.
* The magnetic and electric dipole moments can be represented as the real and imaginary parts of a generalized dipole operator, and the interaction Lagrangian becomes a function of the magnetic and electric fields and dipole moments.
* The electron anomaly is now measured to a relative precision of about four parts in a billion, which is better than the precision on the fine-structure constant, and it has been used to give the best determination of the fine-structure constant.
* The muon anomaly is measured to 0.5 parts per million and is sensitive to 100 GeV scale physics.
* The standard model value of the magnetic moment of the muon has measurable contributions from three types of radiative processes: QED loops containing leptons and photons, hadronic loops containing hadrons in vacuum polarization loops, and weak loops involving the W and Z gauge bosons.
</summary>

- The existence and thermal relic abundance of dark matter (DM) have been established by the WMAP experiment, and the weakly interacting massive particle (WIMP) is a promising candidate.
- The hTM model can accommodate the WIMP DM candidate economically by introducing an inert scalar field with the inert property, ensuring the stability of the DM candidate.
- Neutrinos have nonzero but tiny masses, and the seesaw mechanism and the Higgs triplet model (HTM) are two simple ways to explain them. However, neither contains a DM candidate.
- In models where tiny neutrino masses are generated by higher orders of perturbation, the DM candidate can be naturally contained.
- The HTM introduces right-handed neutrinos with large majorana masses and generates majorana neutrino masses via the yukawa interaction with a nonzero vacuum expectation value (VEV) of a triplet scalar field.
- The lepton number conserving operator which results in the DM candidate is of dimension-5, and the suppression factor for the DM mass is estimated to be much smaller than the electroweak scale.
- The model presents a simple extension of the HTM by introducing a complex singlet scalar, a real singlet scalar, and a doublet scalar field to accommodate the DM candidate and generate the DM-mass-inducing interaction at the one-loop level.
- The model gives small neutrino masses naturally without using very heavy particles, and the suppression factor for the DM relic abundance is constrained by the WMAP experiment.
</summary>

• The text discusses the behavior of Quark-Chromodynamics (QCD) at finite baryon density, which is important for understanding the structure of compact stars and conditions near the core of collapsing stars.
• Sufficiently cold and dense baryonic matter is in the color superconducting phase, proposed by Frautschi and Barrois based on attractive one-gluon exchange between two quarks in the color antitriplet channel.
• The color superconducting phase may exist in the central region of compact stars, but the charge neutrality condition and equilibrium are required to form bulk matter inside them.
• The mismatch between the fermi surfaces of the pairing quarks induces a Cooper pairing that is eventually destroyed with the increase of mismatch, leading to a first-order phase transition from the color superconducting phase to the normal phase.
• The system can also experience a spatial non-uniform Larkin-Ovchinnikov-Fudde-Ferrell (LOFF) state in a certain window of moderate mismatch.
• The charge neutrality condition plays an essential role in determining the ground state of the neutral system, and if it is satisfied globally and the surface tension is small, the mixed phase is favored.
• The homogeneous neutral cold-dense quark matter can be in the gapless 2sc or gapless CFL phase, depending on the flavor structure of the system.
• The meissner effect, which is the superconductor's expulsion of magnetic fields, can be understood using the standard Anderson-Higgs mechanism, but in the g2sc phase, the meissner screening masses for five gluons corresponding to broken generators become imaginary, indicating a type of chromomagnetic instability.

• The text discusses the relation between quantum fluctuation, tunneling, and decoherence in the context of a one-dimensional double-well system driven by a polychromatic external field.
• The authors estimate the degree of coherence of the tunneling probability for various frequency components and perturbation strengths.
• In the coherent motion regime, the period of the tunneling oscillation is reduced as the number of colors and/or strength of the perturbation increase.
• The perturbed instanton picture is used to explain chaos-assisted tunneling in the coherent oscillation regime.
• The uncertainty product grows linearly with time in the stochastically perturbed case but saturates at a certain level in the polychromatically perturbed cases.

• The quantum fluctuations are always larger for classically chaotic trajectories compared to regular ones, implying that quantum corrections to the evolution of the phase space fluctuation become more dominant for classically chaotic trajectories.
• The semiquantal approximation enhances the chaotic behavior and simultaneously enhances the tunneling and decoherence of the wave packet.

• The semiquantal picture cannot apply to chaos-induced delocalized states.

• Active p2p worms utilize the p2p overlay to accurately find vulnerable hosts and infect them, making them more deadly than scanning worms. The proposed system uses phagocytes, a small subset of specially elected p2p hosts, to manage a group of p2p hosts and monitor their connection patterns and traffic volume.
• If any worm events are detected, the phagocyte invokes internal defense strategies for local isolation, alert propagation, and software patching. The phagocytes also provide access control and filtering mechanisms to prevent external attacks and forbid p2p traffic from leaking to external hosts.
• The system uses an adaptive and interaction-based computational puzzle scheme to prevent external hosts from attacking the p2p overlay. The puzzle scheme adjusts the puzzle difficulty based on the real-time statuses of the network environment and effectively prevents malicious external hosts from attacking without investing unbearable resources.

• Dyadic data are common in psychosocial and behavioral studies, particularly in research on interpersonal relationships.
• Members of dyads often influence each other's cognitions, emotions, and behaviors, leading to interdependence in a relationship.
• Interdependence results in correlated observations of the two individuals, and understanding this interdependence is a primary objective of relationship research.
• Longitudinal dyadic data are collected over time, but repeated measures bring complications: within-dyad correlation and the missing data problem caused by dropout.
• Nonignorable dropouts, where the dropout depends on missing values, can lead to severely biased estimates using conventional statistical methods.
• A fully bayesian approach using a selection model is proposed to deal with longitudinal dyadic data with nonignorable dropouts.
• The approach models each subject's longitudinal measurement process using a transition model that includes both members' characteristics and accounts for within-dyad correlation and nonignorable dropouts.
</summary>

The text discusses the importance of dyadic data in psychosocial and behavioral studies, focusing on interpersonal relationships where observations refer to both individuals involved. Members of dyads often influence each other, leading to interdependence and correlated observations. Longitudinal dyadic data are collected over time, but repeated measures bring complications: within-dyad correlation and the missing data problem caused by dropout. Nonignorable dropouts, where the dropout depends on missing values, can lead to severely biased estimates using conventional statistical methods. A fully bayesian approach using a selection model is proposed to deal with longitudinal dyadic data with nonignorable dropouts. The approach models each subject's longitudinal measurement process using a transition model that includes both members' characteristics, accounts for within-dyad correlation, and directly models the relationship between the dropout process and missing outcomes.

- According to quantum electrodynamics, electric and magnetic field fluctuations give rise to a zero-point energy that never vanishes, even in the absence of electromagnetic sources.
- In 1948, Casimir predicted that two electrically neutral metallic parallel plates in vacuum, assumed to be perfect conductors, should attract each other with a force inversely proportional to the fourth power of separation.
- The Casimir effect is due to the difference in zero-point energy between the plates when they are close together compared to when they are at infinite separation.
- Lifshitz, Dzyaloshinskii, and Pitaevskii generalized Casimir's theory to isotropic dielectrics, allowing the force between two uncharged parallel plates with arbitrary dielectric functions to be derived analytically.
- The force between two plates made of the same material is always attractive, while the sign of the force depends on the dielectric properties of the medium in which they are immersed for plates of different materials.
- Parsegian and Weiss derived an equation for the non-retarded van der Waals interaction energy between two dielectrically anisotropic plates immersed in a third anisotropic material.
- Barash and colleagues analyzed a similar problem and found an equation for the Helmholtz free energy (per unit area) of the electromagnetic field in which retardation effects are included.
- The torque between two parallel birefringent slabs placed in an isotropic medium causes them to spontaneously rotate towards the configuration in which their principal axes are aligned.
- The casimir-lifshitz force between isotropic dielectrics has been verified in several high precision experiments, and although most attention has been focused on the interaction between metallic surfaces in vacuum, its general validity is not in doubt.
</summary>

- Blind 21-cm emission line surveys in the local universe have accurately measured the Hi mass, which can be used as a reference point for higher redshift DLAs studies.
- The high-resolution 21-cm maps of a large sample of local galaxies (Whisp) are used to study the column density distribution function of Hi.
- The results show only mild evolution in the intersection cross section of Hi from redshift 2.5 to the present, implying that the local galaxy population explains the incidence rate of low and intermediate redshift DLAs without the need for hidden very low surface brightness (LSB) galaxies or isolated Hi clouds.
- The metallicity distribution for Hi column densities peaks around [o/H]=0.2-0.4, much lower than the mean value of a typical Milky Way galaxy, due to the contribution of sub-L* galaxies and the highest interception probability at larger impact parameters for more luminous, larger galaxies.
- The local galaxy population can explain the incidence rate, metallicities, luminosities, and impact parameters of DLAs.

</summary>

• The relativistic embedding scheme outlined in the text enables the Dirac equation to be solved within a limited region when it forms part of a larger system. The influence of the rest of the system is taken into account by adding an energy-dependent non-local potential to the Hamiltonian for the embedded region.
• The scheme is based on a trial function in which continuity in the small component across the surface separating the embedded and unembedded regions is imposed variationally. The method is demonstrated to be stable and convergent, and the green function for the embedded Hamiltonian is derived and illustrated in the continuum regime. Future applications are expected to be to defects and surfaces of materials containing heavier elements within the framework of density functional theory.

- The text discusses methods to compute couplings of certain single trace operators in $\mathcal{N}=4$ SYM theory.
- Recent progress has been made in finding the spectrum of this theory, but much remains to be done for the couplings.
- At weak coupling, perturbation theory can be used, but it is impractical for general operators.
- A more promising approach is to explore integrability in planar $\mathcal{N}=4$ SYM.
- Deforming the theory with a marginal or irrelevant operator introduces new divergences in the renormalized operators, which can be cancelled by renormalizing the operators.
- The entry of the deformed anomalous dimension matrix between operators is determined by the coupling, allowing for new methods to compute the couplings.
- The dilaton field deformation is an exact deformation, making it a good example to implement these ideas.
- Other deformations, such as the $\mathcal{O}(13)$ deformation, are expected to work in a similar fashion.
- The goal is to unveil new integrability structures in the perturbative computation of the couplings, but this remains an open problem.

<summary>

- The glass transition from a liquid to an amorphous solid is a largely unresolved problem in statistical physics.
- At the experimental level, it is associated with a sharp increase in relaxation times and a departure from equilibrium.
- Theoretically, it has been proposed that an equilibrium transition triggers the glass transition at the Kauzmann temperature.
- Gibbs and Dimarzio were among the first to propose this idea, and more recent studies using replica methods have provided evidence.
- However, experimental data and simulations of polydisperse hard-core disks have failed to detect any evidence of a thermodynamic transition.
- Different theoretical considerations have attempted to establish a connection between glass transition phenomena and the rapid increase in relaxation times near a critical temperature.
- The mode coupling theory (MCT) predicts a transition from a high temperature liquid state to a low temperature arrested state at a critical temperature.
- The full MCT shows no longer a sharp transition at the critical temperature but all structural correlations decay in a final process.
- The value of the critical temperature predicted by the idealized MCT can be calculated from the partial structure factors and their temperature dependence.
</summary>

* The glass transition from a liquid to an amorphous solid is a complex phenomenon that remains unresolved in statistical physics.
* At the experimental level, it is characterized by a sharp increase in relaxation times and a departure from equilibrium.
* Theoretically, it has been proposed that an underlying thermodynamic transition triggers the glass transition at the Kauzmann temperature.
* Gibbs and Dimarzio were among the first to propose this idea, and more recent studies using replica methods have provided evidence.
* However, experimental data and simulations of polydisperse hard-core disks have failed to detect any evidence of a thermodynamic transition.
* Different theoretical considerations have attempted to establish a connection between glass transition phenomena and the rapid increase in relaxation times near a critical temperature.
* The mode coupling theory (MCT) predicts a transition from a high temperature liquid state to a low temperature arrested state at a critical temperature.
* The full MCT shows no longer a sharp transition at the critical temperature but all structural correlations decay in a final process.
* The value of the critical temperature predicted by the idealized MCT can be calculated from the partial structure factors and their temperature dependence.

• The text discusses the study of young massive star clusters using observations and simulations.
• During the formation of star clusters, only a modest percentage of gas is turned into stars, leaving a significant amount of gas within the cluster.
• The loss of gas from the cluster due to stellar winds and supernovae explosions leads to a rapid change in gravitational potential energy, causing the cluster to be out of equilibrium.
• Many studies have attempted to constrain the initial stellar mass function (IMF) in young clusters by measuring their internal dynamics and assuming virial equilibrium.
• However, the youngest clusters (tens of Myr) are likely out of equilibrium, as shown by discrepant results from studies on the IMF.
• The authors propose that this is due to the rapid gas loss from the clusters, which undercuts the assumption of virial equilibrium.
• The authors plan to investigate this scenario by examining the detailed luminosity profiles of three young massive clusters using observations from the Hubble Space Telescope.

</summary>

• The authors present observations of three young massive clusters, m82-f, ngc 1569-a, and ngc 1705-1, using F555W band observations taken with the Hubble Space Telescope's Advanced Camera for Surveys.
• They note that all three clusters display an excess of light at large radii compared to the best fitting power-law profile, which is a signature of rapid gas removal and hence not in dynamical equilibrium.
• The authors also note that the background subtraction is non-trivial due to the large distance and non-uniform background around the clusters, but their conclusions remain unchanged.

• The authors model star clusters using N-body simulations, which require specifying the plummer radius and total mass.
• They confirm previous results that for higher mass clusters, significant stellar mass loss occurs but a bound core remains, while for lower mass clusters, the cluster is totally destroyed by gas expulsion.
• The authors assume a constant mass-to-light ratio for the simulation and convert the projected mass density into a luminosity and hence surface brightness profile.

• The authors find that for clusters with 26% and 27% of the initial mass, they quickly readjust to their new potential and virial mass estimates become fairly accurate.

• Debris disk systems provide a look at an intermediate stage of stellar system evolution, representing the transition between the early formation of stars and planets and the mature stage of an evolved system.
• The observed infrared luminosity of circumstellar dust in debris disks is typically several orders of magnitude larger than estimated for the Kuiper and asteroid belts in our solar system.
• Two absorption components are detected toward hd32297, while only one is detected toward its proximate neighbors located at a comparable distance. The extra absorption component in the spectrum of hd32297, which is also at rest in the stellar reference frame, is therefore likely caused by circumstellar material.
• The ism absorption is similar among hd32297 and its two closest neighbors, and is likely due to absorption from the shell that defines the boundary of the local bubble. Some variation in local bubble absorption is detected toward 18 ori.
• Radial velocities of hd32297, bd+07 777s, and bd+07 778 are measured and differ significantly, indicating that they are likely not physically associated.
• Some indication of temporal variability is detected over several epochs of observations, but instrumental resolution variations and masking by the strong ism absorption make a definitive detection of circumstellar variability difficult.
• The measured circumstellar feature toward hd32297 is the strongest such absorption measured toward any nearby main sequence debris disk, 45 times greater than the column density of the prototypical edge-on debris disk, 0 pic.
• An upper limit to the gas mass in the circumstellar disk surrounding hd32297 is estimated, assuming the morphology and abundances of the stable gas component are similar to 0 pic. Future observations are planned to continue monitoring the temporal variability of the circumstellar gas toward hd32297 to determine the ratio of stable to variable gas and measure the gas disk absorption.

- The analysis of dynamic processes in complex networks, particularly the interplay between network dynamics and network structure adaptation, is a major research area with applications in social, biological, and technological systems.
- The spread of information in online social networks, evolution of epidemic outbreaks in human contact networks, and dynamics of cascading failures in electrical grids are examples of dynamic processes in complex networks.
- Most modeling and analysis techniques are tailored to study static networks, but real-world networks are constantly evolving over time.
- The effects of temporal structural variations on network dynamics are poorly understood, and there is a lack of tools to analyze network adaptation mechanisms and effectively utilize them for containing spreading processes.
- The adaptive susceptible-infected-susceptible (asis) model proposes mechanisms for network structure adaptation in response to epidemics, but analytical results are based on assumptions of homogeneous contact patterns and node/edge dynamics.
- The heterogeneous asis model extends the asis model to arbitrary networks with heterogeneous node and edge dynamics, and derives a lower bound on the epidemic threshold for this model.
- The optimization framework proposed in the study finds cost-optimal adaptation rates to eradicate epidemics and confirms the accuracy of theoretical results with numerical simulations, comparing cost-optimal adaptation rates with popular centrality measures.
</summary>

* The text discusses an experimental investigation of the length spectra of two circular dielectric microwave resonators using a combination of the semiclassical trace formula for 2d dielectric resonators and a 2d approximation of the Helmholtz equation for flat 3d resonators using an effective index of refraction. The results showed good agreement between the experimental length spectra and the trace formula, and the different contributions of the periodic orbits to the length spectra could be successfully identified. However, the positions of the peaks in the experimental length spectrum were slightly shifted with respect to the geometrical lengths of the periodic orbits due to the frequency dependence of the effective index of refraction and a systematic inaccuracy of the approximation.
* The study also found that the effective index of refraction is influenced by the presence of a metal plate parallel to the dielectric disk, leading to a shift of the resonance frequencies. The authors computed the reflection coefficient for a wave traveling inside the dielectric and being reflected at the dielectric-air interface with the metal plate at a distance, and obtained the condition for the effective index of refraction as a function of the distance. They found that for tm modes, the effective index of refraction increases for decreasing distance of the metal plate from the resonator, while for te modes it gets smaller. This behavior is found for the whole range of distances, even when the boundary conditions are no longer valid.

They find that about 96% of coalescences occur above a critical redshift, contributing to the production of a continuous background, while sources in the redshift interval correspond to a duty cycle of 0.1 and are responsible for a cosmic popcorn noise.

• The acoustic oscillations in the matter power spectrum at recombination have a standard ruler scale that can be calculated based on CMB measurements.
• This standard ruler can be measured at low redshifts through large galaxy surveys to constrain the matter and energy content of the universe.
• The interpretation of low-redshift acoustic oscillations is robust if the CMB correctly tells us the baryon-to-photon ratio and the epoch of matter-radiation equality.
• The sound horizon, which depends on the Hubble parameter and sound speed in the baryon-photon plasma, can be used to measure the wavelength of baryonic features in the mass power spectrum.
• Measuring the sound horizon at low redshift can constrain cosmology by predicting distance ratios between low and high redshifts.
• The CMB is sensitive to non-photon radiation density through its effect on equality and the evolution of potentials, allowing us to constrain unknown relativistic species.
• Other cosmological measurements, such as galaxy surveys, weak lensing surveys, and cluster abundance measurements, can be used to measure the actual densities and thereby constrain the presence of unknown relativistic species.
</summary>

- The text describes a bidirectional relay network where users exchange information via a relay node using various protocols under the half-duplex constraint.
- The simplest protocol is the traditional two-way relaying protocol, while the time division broadcast (TDBC) and multiple access broadcast (MABC) protocols are more complex.
- TDBC combines the relay-to-user 1 and relay-to-user 2 phases into one phase, allowing each user to recover its intended information by self-interference cancellation.
- MABC combines the user-to-relay and user-to-relay phases into one phase, allowing both users to transmit to the relay simultaneously.
- The goal is to utilize all available degrees of freedom of the three-node half-duplex bidirectional relay network with fading using an adaptive mode selection and power allocation policy.

- The text also mentions the importance of adaptive link selection and power control for rate maximization in fading awgn channels.
- The authors propose an optimization problem to find a policy that selects the optimal transmission mode and allocates the optimal powers to the nodes in each time slot to maximize the sum rate.

• Quantum channel estimation is the problem of determining the properties of a quantum channel using finite resources.
• The text focuses on the estimation of one-parameter quantum channels, specifically the depolarizing, phase damping, and amplitude damping channels.
• The depolarizing channel is a good model for quantum information encoded in photon polarization and is described by a single parameter.
• The phase damping channel is a good model for decoherence and acts on two components of the Bloch vector, leaving the third unchanged.
• The amplitude damping channel affects all components of the Bloch vector and is a good model for spontaneous decay from an atomic excited state to the ground state.
• The text also explores the use of entanglement as a powerful resource in quantum channel estimation.
• The determination of all properties of a quantum channel is important for any quantum communication protocol, and methods to gain this knowledge are essential.
</summary>

• Shock acceleration of cosmic rays is a complex phenomenon with important nonlinear effects, including the backreaction of accelerated particles on the shock.
• Three approaches have been proposed to account for this backreaction: numerical simulations, fluid models, and analytical methods.
• Analytical methods can provide insights into the physics of nonlinear effects, but have limitations in reproducing the full spectrum of accelerated particles.
• Recent studies have investigated the effects of nonlinear backreaction on the maximum achievable energy and the presence of seed particles.
• A practical solution for the nonlinear regime is needed, and promising analytical solutions have recently appeared in the literature.
• Numerical simulations have shown that even a small fraction of particles injected from the thermal gas can significantly affect the shock, leading to a flattening of the particle spectrum at high energies.
• The authors present the first analytical treatment of shock acceleration in the presence of seed nonthermal particles, including their nonlinear backreaction on the shock.

• Detailed discussions of the current status of investigations into diffusive acceleration at Newtonian shock fronts can be found in recent reviews.
• Much is now well understood, but some issues, such as the backreaction of accelerated particles on the shock, are still subjects of much debate.
• The backreaction occurs when the acceleration process becomes efficient enough to generate pressures of the accelerated particles comparable to the incoming gas kinetic pressure.

• Three viable approaches to account for the backreaction of particles upon the shock are: numerical simulations, fluid models, and analytical methods.
• Numerical simulations allow for a self-consistent treatment of several effects, but are computationally intensive.
• Fluid models treat cosmic rays as a relativistic second fluid, allowing for the thermodynamics of the modified shocks to be obtained but not providing information about the spectrum of accelerated particles.

• Analytical methods can provide valuable insights into the physics of nonlinear effects, but have limitations in reproducing the full spectrum of accelerated particles.
• Recent studies have investigated the effects of nonlinear backreaction on the maximum achievable energy and the presence of seed particles.
• A practical solution for the nonlinear regime is needed, and promising analytical solutions have recently appeared in the literature.

- The contact pattern among individuals in a population is crucial for the spread of infectious diseases. Scale-free networks, which have a power-law degree distribution, are commonly observed in real-world networks, including human sexual contacts.
- Scale-free networks exhibit a high degree of heterogeneity, with many vertices having a low number of contacts and a few vertices having a high number of contacts. This heterogeneity may influence the potential risk of spread of acute and chronic diseases.
- The authors simulated the spread of acute and chronic infectious diseases on scale-free networks with the same degree distribution but different topological structures using SI and SIS epidemic models. They found that networks with different structural properties had distinct impacts on the dynamics of epidemics.
- The authors generated scale-free networks using the Barabasi-Albert algorithm and compared their dynamics to networks generated using other methods, such as MA, MB, Molloy-Reed, and Kalisky algorithms. They observed that networks generated by different methods had distinct structural properties.
- The authors simulated the spread of diseases on undirected and directed networks and observed that the prevalence tends to stabilize approximately in the same level despite the addition of vertices. However, the prevalence in directed networks was smaller than in undirected networks due to the limitations imposed by the direction of the movements.
- The authors found that the networks generated using the BA algorithm presented the lowest values of prevalence in the spreading simulations. They also observed that the prevalence in the kalisky networks tended to stabilize in a level a little bit higher than the other ones.
- The authors concluded that their approach, focusing on different networks with the same degree distribution, allows for a better understanding of how the topological features of a network may influence the dynamics on the network. They also emphasized the importance of preventing potentially infectious contacts in cases of sanitary emergencies.

- The text discusses a method to understand Lindblad evolution as an averaged random unitary evolution using stochastic methods and operator techniques.
- The result holds for both markovian and nonmarkovian Lindbladian master equations with selfadjoint Lindblad operators.
- The flexibility of the mathematical language employed allows for the generalization of intrinsic decoherence models present in the literature.

The text discusses a novel attempt to derive Lindblad master equations (MEs) in both the markovian and nonmarkovian regimes using stochastic methods and well-known operator techniques. The main idea is to build random evolution operators containing the decohering effect of the environment and then take the stochastic expectation value with respect to this uncontrollable randomness. The result shows that any Lindblad-type ME with selfadjoint Lindblad operators can be understood as an averaged random unitary evolution. The paper also discusses some mathematical consequences of this result, such as a fast method to solve MEs and the generalization of intrinsic decoherence models. The flexibility of the mathematical language employed allows for the derivation of both markovian and nonmarkovian MEs and the generalization of existing intrinsic decoherence models. The proposed formalism can also account for reported exponential decays of Rabi oscillations in ion traps and can be used to solve Lindbladian nonmarkovian master equations. The use of stochastic processes in quantum mechanics has potential physical interpretations and utility in solving certain master equations.

• Cr-doped dilute magnetic semiconductors (DMS) and Cr-based alloys, particularly CrAs and CrSB in zinc blende (ZB) structure, have attracted attention due to their possible complete spin polarization and high Curie temperatures.

• Cold atoms in optical lattices is a fusion of quantum gases from atomic physics and laser theory from quantum optics.
• Optical lattices are artificial crystals of light, formed by interference of two or more laser beams, creating a periodic intensity pattern.
• Atoms can be cooled and trapped in these optical lattices, creating a crystal of quantum matter.
• The success of observing the superfluid to Mott insulator (sf-mi) transition led to the possibility of using optical lattices as a test laboratory for phenomena in condensed matter physics.
• Bose-Einstein condensation (BEC) was first predicted by Satyendra Nath Bose and Albert Einstein in 1924, and was later observed in rubidium atoms in 1995.
• BEC is a state where almost all particles in a bosonic system congregate in the ground state at a finite temperature.
• The observation of BEC led to the observation of the sf-mi transition, which is important in condensed matter physics.
• The two-mode approximation is used to study spin ordering in an isolated double-well-type potential, which is a simple experimental setup for optical lattices.
• The potential bias or tilt of the double well is introduced by changing the relative phase of the two potentials, which can be realized by applying a magnetic field gradient.
• The ground state energy is negative and modified by the presence of potential bias, and the energy difference between the ground state and first excited state is small in the weak potential bias regime.

• The present calculations describe the @xmath2he core only by its ground-state wave function and use SRG evolved potentials obtained from the chiral NN interaction.

• The cataclysmic variable HU Aqr consists of a 0.80 white dwarf and a 0.18 main-sequence companion star. The transfer of mass in the tight orbit is mediated by gravitational waves and the strong magnetic field of the accreting star.
• Detailed timing analysis revealed the presence of two planets: a 5.7 planet in a 0.013 orbit with an eccentricity of 0.22, and a 7.6 planet in a wider and eccentric orbit. However, the two-planet configuration is dynamically unstable on a 100,000-year timescale, but some numerical simulations exhibit long-term dynamical stability.
• The presence of planets around a cataclysmic variable offers unique diagnostics to constrain the origin and evolution of the system. The inner planet allows us to break the degeneracy and derive the rate of mass loss in the common-envelope phase, while the outer planet validates this calculation and determines the conditions under which the cv was born.
• The common-envelope phase results in the primary's mantle being blown away beyond the planets' orbits, causing them to migrate to their currently observed orbits. The response of the orbit to mass loss depends on the total amount of mass lost and the rate at which it is lost. Numerical common-envelope studies indicate that the entire envelope can be expelled impulsively, leading to the possible loss of the planet.

• The text discusses the core entropy of quadratic polynomials and its extension to complex polynomials. The core entropy is the topological entropy of a polynomial restricted to its hubbard tree, a finite topological tree that is forward invariant under the polynomial. The main goal of the paper is to prove that the core entropy function extends continuously from the set of postcritically finite parameters to the complex plane.
• The text also introduces Thurston's algorithm for computing the core entropy of rational angles and shows how it can be extended to any angle using labeled wedges and infinite graphs. The algorithm involves constructing a matrix whose leading eigenvalue gives the core entropy, and the logarithm of the eigenvalue is shown to be equal to the core entropy for rational angles. The paper also discusses the relationship between the core entropy and the Hausdorff dimension of the set of biaccessible angles, and the asymptotic stretch factor of dendritic Julia sets.

• The experimental discovery of skyrmions in non-centrosymmetric compounds with dzyaloshinskii-moriya interaction, specifically in mnsi films, has attracted scientific interest.
• Mnsi films offer magnetic phases of interest and are easy to integrate into devices due to the use of silicon as a substrate material.
• However, the low magnetic ordering temperature of mnsi is a drawback, leading researchers to seek compounds with similar spin order at higher temperatures.
• Mnge, a b20 compound with a magnetic ordering temperature of 170K and a helical spin structure, is a promising candidate.
• A large topological hall effect and small angle neutron scattering experiments provide evidence for the existence of skyrmions in mnge.
• The synthesis of mnge is laborious due to its requirement for high pressure and temperatures.
• Molecular beam epitaxy (MBE) allows for thin film growth under strong non-equilibrium conditions, offering an opportunity to prepare mnge on silicon substrates.
• The lattice constant of mnge within the (111) plane matches that of silicon with a misfit of only 2%, enabling the growth of compressively strained mnge films on silicon substrates.
• The preparation method for mnge thin films on silicon substrates using a mnsi seedlayer is presented in the paper, with the structure and morphology of the films investigated using reflection high-energy electron diffraction (RHEED), atomic force microscopy (AFM), and x-ray diffraction (XRD).
